skill.name: dispatching-parallel-agents
skill.description: Use when facing 3+ independent failures that can be investigated without shared state or dependencies. Dispatches multiple Claude agents to investigate and fix independent problems concurrently.
skill.summary: Dispatch multiple Claude agents concurrently to investigate and fix 3+ independent problems without shared state.
skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: All 28 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown code blocks as shell commands, flagged common documentation words as C2 keywords, and misidentified JSON metadata as file system access. This is legitimate skill documentation about parallel agent dispatching patterns.

content.value_statement: When facing multiple independent failures, sequential investigation wastes time. This skill provides a proven pattern to dispatch multiple Claude agents concurrently, reducing investigation time by up to 3x while avoiding resource conflicts.
actual_capabilities: Identify independent problem domains that can be solved in isolation
Create focused agent prompts with clear scope boundaries
Dispatch 3+ agents concurrently using Task tool parallel execution
Merge results from parallel agents without conflicts
limitations: Only works when problems are truly independent with no shared state
Cannot handle scenarios requiring whole-system context
Agents must not interfere with shared resources
Relies on proper problem decomposition by the user

use_cases.title: Debug Multiple Independent Failures
use_cases.description: When your test suite reports 3+ failures in different modules (auth, API, database), dispatch separate agents to investigate each in parallel. Each agent focuses on one module without stepping on others.
use_cases.target_user: Software engineers debugging complex test failures

use_cases.title: Parallelize Code Review Tasks
use_cases.description: Review multiple pull requests or feature branches simultaneously by sending agents to analyze different code areas. Each agent returns findings that are then consolidated.
use_cases.target_user: Tech leads and code reviewers managing large codebases

use_cases.title: Simultaneous Documentation Updates
use_cases.description: Update documentation across multiple sections or services at once. Each agent handles a specific documentation area, ensuring consistent formatting while avoiding conflicts.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Parallel Dispatch
prompt_templates.prompt:
We have multiple independent failures to investigate:

## Problem 1
Scope: [file/area 1]
Goal: Find the root cause of [specific issue]

## Problem 2
Scope: [file/area 2]
Goal: Find the root cause of [specific issue]

## Problem 3
Scope: [file/area 3]
Goal: Find the root cause of [specific issue]

Dispatch these as 3 parallel agents. Each agent should only modify files in their assigned scope.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting parallel investigation of 3+ independent issues

prompt_templates.title: Parallel Fix Execution
prompt_templates.prompt:
The root causes have been identified. Now dispatch agents to implement fixes:

## Fix Agent 1
Target: [file 1]
Change: [specific fix description]

## Fix Agent 2
Target: [file 2]
Change: [specific fix description]

Run these in parallel. Verify tests pass after each fix.
prompt_templates.scenario: Implementing fixes identified during parallel investigation

prompt_templates.title: Concurrent Feature Development
prompt_templates.prompt:
Build these independent features concurrently:

## Feature 1
Path: [module 1]
Deliverable: [feature specification]

## Feature 2
Path: [module 2]
Deliverable: [feature specification]

## Feature 3
Path: [module 3]
Deliverable: [feature specification]

Dispatch agents to work on each feature. Return code changes for review.
prompt_templates.scenario: Developing multiple independent features in parallel

prompt_templates.title: Parallel Testing Campaign
prompt_templates.prompt:
Run tests across these independent test suites concurrently:

## Suite 1
Scope: [test directory 1]
Focus: [test category]

## Suite 2
Scope: [test directory 2]
Focus: [test category]

## Suite 3
Scope: [test directory 3]
Focus: [test category]

Execute in parallel. Collect and compare results.

output_examples.input: We have 4 test failures in different files: auth.test.js, api.test.js, db.test.js, and cache.test.js. All are independent.
output: Agent 1: Investigating auth.test.js - Found JWT token expiration issue at auth/jwt.js:45
Agent 2: Investigating api.test.js - Found middleware ordering issue at api/routes.js:12
Agent 3: Investigating db.test.js - Found connection pool exhaustion at db/config.js:8
Agent 4: Investigating cache.test.js - Found TTL configuration at cache/redis.js:23
All 4 issues identified and fixed in parallel. Tests passing.

output_examples.input: Update documentation for these 3 independent modules in parallel.
output: Agent 1: Updated API documentation at docs/api/ - Added new endpoint examples
Agent 2: Updated authentication docs at docs/auth/ - Added OAuth flow diagrams
Agent 3: Updated deployment docs at docs/deploy/ - Added container configuration
Documentation updated across all 3 modules with consistent formatting

best_practices: Clearly define scope boundaries for each agent to prevent overlap
Use the Task tool parallel execution pattern (Task A || Task B || Task C)
Include explicit constraints like 'do not modify files outside scope'
anti_patterns: Dispatching agents when problems share state or dependencies
Leaving scope definitions too broad, causing agent conflicts
Not providing clear constraints, leading to duplicate work

faq.question: What makes problems independent?
faq.answer: Problems are independent when fixing one does not affect the others, they operate on different files or modules, and they do not require shared context to diagnose.

faq.question: How many agents can I dispatch at once?
faq.answer: The Task tool supports parallel dispatch. Three to five concurrent agents typically work well, depending on your Claude Code configuration.

faq.question: What happens if agents conflict on the same file?
faq.answer: Clear scope definitions prevent conflicts. If scopes overlap, coordinate sequentially or split the work differently.

faq.question: Can I mix parallel and sequential execution?
faq.answer: Yes. Run groups of independent problems in parallel, then sequence dependent groups. This handles partial dependencies.

faq.question: How do I verify results from parallel agents?
faq.answer: Each agent should return structured findings. Compare results, run tests, and merge changes using standard version control.

faq.question: When should I avoid this pattern?
faq.answer: Avoid when problems require shared context, when fixes might affect each other, or when system-wide changes are needed.
